subject: Add logging when filtering returns nothing.
commit_message:
Add logging when filtering returns nothing.

When hosts are filtered for a request, and no host passes all the
filters, operators can only see the last filter run; they have no
visibility into which filter removed which host. This attempts to
improve this situation by tracking the hosts remaining after each
filter is run and the number of hosts removed. If no host is left, to
log that information along with the reservation ID and instance UUID
of the request. Since that can be a lot of information, it will call
LOG.info with just the counts for all but the final filter, which
will contain the last deleted host names; LOG.debug will output the
full record of each filter and the hosts remaining after each step.
This will better enable operators to determine why a particular host
was not selected.

subject: Filter deleted instances when doing a detailed list with all_tenants=1
commit_message:
Filter deleted instances when doing a detailed list with all_tenants=1

There can be a race when listing details for instances in all_tenants
between the time that we get the instances from the database and when we
lazy-load attributes on them in the view builder, like the flavor
attribute.

In the case of Tempest, this could simply be because the admin is
listing details on all instances which is picking up servers from tests
running in parallel, and those tests are deleting instances between the
time we got the instances from the database and when we hit the view
builder.

This change handles InstanceNotFound when building the view on the list
of instances and ignores/filters deleted instances iff the request was
made with the all_tenants flag.  This assumes that the servers API
pre-filtered the search options and validated that the admin context is
being used to get all of the instances up front before hitting the view
builder.

Alternatives to this approach:

1. Pre-load info_cache, flavor and metadata attributes in the server
   API when fetching the instances so that lazy-loading doesn't happen.
   The problem with this is it tightly couples the attributes that we
   need to get up front to what the view builder is showing, and those
   would have to be kept in sync if we ever expose new attributes on
   the instance.

2. When lazy-loading object attributes, use read_deleted='yes'. There
   are two downsides to this:

   a) We want to move away from soft delete so we should avoid reading
      deleted resources as much as possible, especially from the API.

   b) If the instance is actually deleted, then the results of the list

subject: Neutron RBAC API and network support
commit_message:
Neutron RBAC API and network support

This adds the new API endpoint to create, update, and delete
role-based access control entries. These entries enable tenants
to grant access to other tenants to perform an action on an object
they do not own.

This was previously done using a single 'shared' flag; however, this
was too coarse because an object would either be private to a tenant
or it would be shared with every tenant.

In addition to introducing the API, this patch also adds support to
for the new entries in Neutron networks. This means tenants can now
share their networks with specific tenants as long as they know the
tenant ID.

This feature is backwards-compatible with the previous 'shared'
attribute in the API. So if a deployer doesn't want this new feature
enabled, all of the RBAC operations can be blocked in policy.json and
networks can still be globally shared in the legacy manner.

Even though this feature is referred to as role-based access control,
this first version only supports sharing networks with specific
tenant IDs because Neutron currently doesn't have integration with
Keystone to handle changes in a tenant's roles/groups/etc.

DocImpact
APIImpact

subject: Xenapi: Correct misaligned partitioning
commit_message:
Xenapi: Correct misaligned partitioning

This small commit addresses a misalignment issue within the xenapi
drivers.  Currently within xenapi.vm_utils, _generate_disk  will
partition the disk starting at '0'.  This misalignment may cause some
disk read/write speeds to be less than optimal due to attempting to
start at '1' rather than at the start of a sector.

Changing this value to '2048' aligns the partition.  Internal testing
results have shown this change to significantly improve read speeds
to virtual ephemeral drives, while also improving write speeds to the
disk (although to a lesser degree).

Closes-Bug: #1487300

subject: Ensure LPM'd VMs don't obscure Host CPU stats
commit_message:
Ensure LPM'd VMs don't obscure Host CPU stats

When a Virtual Machine is live migrated from one system to another, the
Host statistics are also migrated along with it.  When this occurs, the
PCM API will not have a previous sample for it.

The existing code assumed the only case that a previous sample may not
be there is if the VM had just spawned.  In which case, all of the
cycles could be attributed to just used.

However, given this LPM behavior, one can not simply add all of the CPU
cycles.  Suddenly the metric could obtain a month's (or whatever the
life of the LPM'd VM is) of data added.  The Host CPU metrics would be
too high and would be inaccurate.

This change throws out samples for VMs for which there is no previous
data.  While not ideal, it strikes a good balance for the issue.  A

subject: Pass requested networks to scheduler filter_props
commit_message:
Pass requested networks to scheduler filter_props

In Icehouse, the nova-scheduler still had a primary responsibility
in orchestrating a VM's deployment and, as such, had access to the
requested_networks via the schedule_run_instance(...) method. In Juno,
we've switched to a model in which the conductor takes over more of
this capability and only invokes the scheduler's select_destination
method.

As a result, the scheduler no longer has any way to determine
which networks are being requested, leaving schedulers unable to
determine which networks the user is requesting at deploy time since
there are no other associations formed at this time.

This patch sends the requested_networks along to the scheduler's
select_destinations() method via filter_props['requested_networks'],
thus allowing schedulers to interrogate this information at VM
initial deploy time.

subject: Eventlet green threads not released back to pool
commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection.
Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Add a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout
behaviour. Allows closing idle client connections after a period of
time, eg:

$ time nc localhost 8776
real    1m0.063s

Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

monasca_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => 'bar' } # will work as usual

if $myvar {

  monasca_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : ensure => absent }

monasca_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => $myvar }

a specific parameter. One could by pass that doing the following :

monasca_config { 'DEFAULT/foo' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>',

commit_message:
lxc: fix disk_info passed to _create_domain_and_network in _hard_reboot

Commit a7a0b4e542a65b3ba3650db2b7560eb587b9606c changed
_get_instance_disk_info to return a list rather than a json string.  As
part of that, it overwrote the local disk_info variable (which was a
dict) in _hard_reboot before it was passed to
_create_domain_and_network.  Eventually when disk_info gets down to
_create_domain_setup_lxc it fails the _is_booted_from_volume because
it's a list rather than a dict.

This moves the _get_instance_disk_info call in _hard_reboot within the
context.auth_token block since the return value is otherwise not needed,
and creates a unique local variable for the instance disk_info so it
doesn't collide with the disk_info that comes back from
blockinfo.get_disk_info.

At some point we should create objects for these various disk_info
variables because otherwise it's really confusing trying to track the
types and usage of all of these different things called 'disk_info'
which are sometimes dicts and sometimes lists of dicts.

package is put in MOS repo. When we create
partial ubuntu mirror we do not put dh-python
package into the partial mirror. But then
when we use this partial mirror together with
debootstrap (which does not support multiple mirrors)
the base operating system can not be installed
because python3 package requires dh-python.

Besides, those packages which are listed explicitly
in fuel_agent/drivers/nailgun.py#L602-L644 should
be also explicitly mentioned in requirements-deb.txt.
